items.title: Elon Musk’s $1 Trillion Pay Vote Sparks ‘TRILLIONS’ Token Frenzy
Elon Musk wins approval for record $1 trillion Tesla pay package
items.standfirst: Tesla shareholders voted on Thursday to approve CEO Elon Musk’s record-breaking pay deal – the largest in corporate history – endorsing his ambitious plan to transform the electric carmaker into a powerhouse of artificial intelligence and robotics. The package could grant Musk stock worth up to $1 trillion over the next decade.
items.content: Tesla shareholders voted on Thursday to approve CEO Elon Musk’s record-breaking pay deal – the largest in corporate history – endorsing his ambitious plan to transform the electric carmaker into a powerhouse of artificial intelligence and robotics. The package could grant Musk stock worth up to $1 trillion over the next decade.

items.title: How Tesla shareholders put Elon Musk on path to be world’s first trillionaire
items.standfirst: A staggering compensation package has been approved – but what does Musk have to do to reap the full rewards?Now that Tesla stockholders have approved a plan to offer Elon Musk close to $1tn, the clock is ticking to make the company worth eight times more than it is today.If Musk can grow Tesla to over $8tn in value for stockholders over the next decade, he will be well on his way to becoming the world’s first trillionaire. Continue reading...

items.title: Tesla shareholders approve $1tn pay package for Elon Musk
items.standfirst: Chants of ‘Elon’ erupt after compensation plan approved despite opposition from several high-profile investorsTesla shareholders approved a $1tn compensation plan for CEO Elon Musk on Thursday, awarding the world’s richest person what would be the largest corporate payout in history if he meets the goals necessary to receive it.The pay package, which several high-profile investors opposed, demonstrates that shareholders still believe Musk can lead the automaker in an era dominated by robotics and artificial intelligence. Continue reading...

Musk would have to meet certain goals to get the full payout. Bloomberg's Ed Ludlow reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

clusters.title: Typhoon Kalmaegi hits Vietnam after unleashing deadly destruction in the Philippines
clusters.neutral_headline: Typhoon Kalmaegi Causes Deaths and Destruction in Southeast Asia

items.title: Typhoon Kalmaegi hits Vietnam after unleashing deadly destruction in the Philippines
items.standfirst: Typhoon Kalmaegi tore across Vietnam early Friday, killing at least five people after leaving a trail of destruction in the Philippines, where authorities said the death toll had climbed to at least 188 following record rains and flooding.
items.content: Typhoon Kalmaegi tore across Vietnam early Friday, killing at least five people after leaving a trail of destruction in the Philippines, where authorities said the death toll had climbed to at least 188 following record rains and flooding.

items.content: One of the year's deadliest storms has headed west to Cambodia and Laos after barreling through Vietnam.

items.content: Typhoon Kalmaegi is tearing through Vietnam and Cambodia after the storm hit the Philippines, leaving at least 114 people dead. NBC News' Ellison Barber has more on the destruction.

items.title: Watch: Cars pile up on Philippines streets after typhoon

items.content: Floods have swept through towns, killing at least 85 people and leaving 75 others missing.

items.title: Philippines declares state of emergency after typhoon Kalmaegi death toll passes 100
items.standfirst: The deaths were mostly from drowning in flash floods, with 127 people still missing, many in the hard-hit central province of CebuPhilippine president Ferdinand Marcos Jr has declared a state of emergency after typhoon Kalmaegi left at least 114 people dead and nearly 130 missing in central provinces in the deadliest natural disaster to hit the country this year.The deaths were mostly from drowning in flash floods, and 127 people were still missing, many in the hard-hit central province of Cebu. The tropical cyclone blew out of the archipelago on Wednesday into the South China Sea. Continue reading...
items.content: The deaths were mostly from drowning in flash floods, with 127 people still missing, many in the hard-hit central province of CebuPhilippine president Ferdinand Marcos Jr has declared a state of emergency after typhoon Kalmaegi left at least 114 people dead and nearly 130 missing in central provinces in the deadliest natural disaster to hit the country this year.The deaths were mostly from drowning in flash floods, and 127 people were still missing, many in the hard-hit central province of Cebu. The tropical cyclone blew out of the archipelago on Wednesday into the South China Sea. Continue reading...

items.content: The Philippines has declared a state of emergency after a typhoon left at least 114 dead and 127 missing.

clusters.title: Sudan's paramilitary group agrees on truce amid accusations of war crimes
clusters.neutral_headline: Sudan Paramilitary Group Agrees to Humanitarian Ceasefire

items.title: Sudan's paramilitary group agrees on truce amid accusations of war crimes
items.standfirst: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, at war with the regular army for more than two years, say they have agreed to a proposal for a humanitarian truce put forward by Emirat, Saudi, Egyptian and US mediators. Two days earlier the Sudanese army had rejected the truce, putting forth its own plan to create a humanitarian corridor.
items.content: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, at war with the regular army for more than two years, say they have agreed to a proposal for a humanitarian truce put forward by Emirat, Saudi, Egyptian and US mediators. Two days earlier the Sudanese army had rejected the truce, putting forth its own plan to create a humanitarian corridor.

items.title: Sudan ceasefire: Political solution without accountability 'will be unstable' and doomed to fail
items.standfirst: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, at war with the regular army for more than two years, announced that they had agreed to a proposal for a humanitarian truce put forward by mediators. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, François Picard welcomes Roaa Elhag, Sudanese Journalist based in London.
items.content: Sudan's paramilitary Rapid Support Forces, at war with the regular army for more than two years, announced that they had agreed to a proposal for a humanitarian truce put forward by mediators. For in-depth analysis and a deeper perspective, François Picard welcomes Roaa Elhag, Sudanese Journalist based in London.

items.title: Sudanese militia group accused of war crimes agrees to a ceasefire
items.standfirst: International mediators broker three-month halt to civil war as further evidence emerges of mass civilian killingsA Sudanese paramilitary group accused of killing thousands of unarmed civilians in an ethnically motivated massacre has agreed to a truce.The Rapid Support Forces (RSF), which is facing mounting criticism over apparent war crimes committed by its fighters in the city of El Fasher last month, said it had agreed to a “humanitarian ceasefire” put forward by the quad countries of the US, Egypt, the UAE and Saudi Arabia. Continue reading...
items.content: International mediators broker three-month halt to civil war as further evidence emerges of mass civilian killingsA Sudanese paramilitary group accused of killing thousands of unarmed civilians in an ethnically motivated massacre has agreed to a truce.The Rapid Support Forces (RSF), which is facing mounting criticism over apparent war crimes committed by its fighters in the city of El Fasher last month, said it had agreed to a “humanitarian ceasefire” put forward by the quad countries of the US, Egypt, the UAE and Saudi Arabia. Continue reading...

items.content: The group issued the statement after an 18-month siege of the city of el-Fasher in the western Darfur region.

items.title: Paramilitary group accused of killing thousands agrees to a ceasefire proposal after massacre in Sudan
items.standfirst: A paramilitary group accused of killing thousands of Sudanese civilians in a war that has triggered a catastrophic humanitarian crisis said Thursday it had agreed to a ceasefire proposal from U.S.-led mediators, although an American official indicated a final deal had not been struck yet
items.content: A paramilitary group accused of killing thousands of Sudanese civilians in a war that has triggered a catastrophic humanitarian crisis said Thursday it had agreed to a ceasefire proposal from U.S.-led mediators, although an American official indicated a final deal had not been struck yet

The ceasefire was proposed by the US, Egypt, UAE, and Saudi Arabia.
The Sudanese army had previously rejected a truce proposal.
The RSF is accused of war crimes, including mass civilian killings.
The ceasefire aims to provide humanitarian aid to the affected areas.

clusters.title: China’s latest aircraft carrier enters service to extend reach into high seas

items.title: China’s latest aircraft carrier enters service to extend reach into high seas
items.standfirst: Experts say hi-tech Fujian will help expand country’s military influence and reach farther beyond its own watersChina’s newest and most advanced aircraft carrier officially entered service this week, signalling a new era in Chinese military expansion after a ceremony overseen by the country’s leader, Xi Jinping, state media has confirmed.The Fujian is China’s first domestically designed and built aircraft carrier, and the third for China’s rapidly expanding navy, which is already the world’s biggest by ship count. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Kazakhstan joins Abraham Accords after White House summit
clusters.neutral_headline: Kazakhstan to Join Abraham Accords, Boosting Trump Initiative

items.title: Kazakhstan joins Abraham Accords after White House summit
items.standfirst: The Abraham Accords was a hallmark achievement for US President Donald Trump's first term. The diplomatic agreements established normalisation between Israel and several countries including the UAE and Bahrain --the first Arab States to do so since Jordan in 1994. On November 6, Trump announced that Kazakhstan, the Former Soviet Republic will be joining them following a summit held at the White House between the US and several Central Asian countries.
items.content: The Abraham Accords was a hallmark achievement for US President Donald Trump's first term. The diplomatic agreements established normalisation between Israel and several countries including the UAE and Bahrain --the first Arab States to do so since Jordan in 1994. On November 6, Trump announced that Kazakhstan, the Former Soviet Republic will be joining them following a summit held at the White House between the US and several Central Asian countries.

items.title: Kazakhstan to join Abraham Accords with Israel in symbolic boost to Trump initiative
items.standfirst: The action, announced Thursday, is largely seen as symbolic. Kazakhstan has had diplomatic relations with Israel since 1992.
items.content: The action, announced Thursday, is largely seen as symbolic. Kazakhstan has had diplomatic relations with Israel since 1992.(Image credit: Vladimir Smirnov)

items.title: Kazakhstan will join Abraham Accords with Israel in symbolic move to boost Trump initiative
items.standfirst: Kazakhstan will join the Abraham Accords between Israel and Muslim majority countries, a largely symbolic move that boosts the initiative that was a hallmark of President Donald Trump's first administration.
items.content: Kazakhstan will join the Abraham Accords between Israel and Muslim majority countries, a largely symbolic move that boosts the initiative that was a hallmark of President Donald Trump's first administration.

items.title: Kazakhstan to join Abraham Accords, Trump says after call with Tokayev
items.standfirst: U.S. President Donald Trump announced on Thursday that Kazakhstan will join the Abraham Accords, expanding the normalisation framework between Israel and Muslim-majority nations. The move, confirmed after Trump’s call with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Kazakh President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, marks the first new entrant to the accords since Trump returned to office.
items.content: U.S. President Donald Trump announced on Thursday that Kazakhstan will join the Abraham Accords, expanding the normalisation framework between Israel and Muslim-majority nations. The move, confirmed after Trump’s call with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and Kazakh President Kassym-Jomart Tokayev, marks the first new entrant to the accords since Trump returned to office.

ai_summary: Kazakhstan will join the Abraham Accords, a symbolic move.
The move was announced by Donald Trump after a summit.
Kazakhstan has had diplomatic relations with Israel since 1992.
The Abraham Accords aim to normalize relations with Israel.
The move is seen as a boost to Trump's foreign policy.

items.content: A deal would bulk up Comcast’s footprint in Europe, where it already owns pay-TV operator Sky, and leave British broadcaster ITV focused on its studios operations.

items.title: US travellers face shutdown-driven flight cancellations
items.standfirst: The longest government shutdown in US history is crippling the country's transportation sector. As airports experience severe staff shortages and air traffic controllers work unpaid, the transport Secretary Sean Duffy has ordered a 10% flight reduction at 40 major US airports, effective November 7, unless a deal to end the government shutdown is reached.
items.content: The longest government shutdown in US history is crippling the country's transportation sector. As airports experience severe staff shortages and air traffic controllers work unpaid, the transport Secretary Sean Duffy has ordered a 10% flight reduction at 40 major US airports, effective November 7, unless a deal to end the government shutdown is reached.

items.title: What Airlines Say About Refunds As Flights Are Impacted by Shutdown

U.S. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy warned that air travel capacity will gradually be cut by up to the…

items.standfirst: Shares fall as users urged to stop using bikes immediately and warned assembly poses risk of falls and injuriesThe US Consumer Product Safety Commission said on Thursday that Peloton Interactive was recalling about 833,000 units of its Original Bike+ Model PL02 after reports that the seat post assembly could break during use, posing a risk of falls and injuries.The consumer safety regulator said the fitness products maker had received three reports of the seat post breaking and detaching during use, including two incidents that resulted in injuries from falls.
